summary: This is an email chain from February 2022 regarding the purchase of courtroom sketches from the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. An individual is seeking to buy sketches of themselves and their partner, who testified for the defense and was depicted setting up a massage table. The illustrator Elizabeth Williams responds, identifying which sketches she drew and mentioning other artists.

persons.name: Elizabeth Williams
persons.context: The illustrator who created sketches during the Ghislaine Maxwell trial and is corresponding about selling prints or originals of her work.

persons.name: Jane Rosenberg
persons.context: Mentioned as the artist who drew the first sketch in the set, which depicted the back of the person inquiring.

persons.name: Christine Cornell
persons.context: Mentioned as the artist who drew one of the other sketches attached to the email.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the trial for which the courtroom sketches were created; her trial is the context for the correspondence.

connections.description: Both are courtroom sketch artists who worked on the Ghislaine Maxwell trial, as indicated by Williams attributing one sketch to Rosenberg.
Both are courtroom sketch artists who worked on the Ghislaine Maxwell trial, as indicated by Williams attributing one sketch to Cornell.

events.title: Inquiry for Maxwell Trial Sketches
events.description: An individual emails courtroom sketch artist Elizabeth Williams seeking to purchase sketches of themselves and their partner from the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
events.description: The criminal trial of Ghislaine Maxwell, referenced as the event where the courtroom sketches were created.

keyFacts: An individual involved in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial is seeking to purchase courtroom sketches depicting themselves setting up a massage table and their partner testifying for the defense.
Courtroom sketch artists Elizabeth Williams, Jane Rosenberg, and Christine Cornell created sketches during the Maxwell trial.
The correspondence reveals post-trial interest in acquiring visual records from the proceedings, indicating the ongoing public and personal significance of the case.
The email chain highlights the role of sketch artists in documenting high-profile trials where photography is restricted.
